awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a system that could improve access to safe airway intubation. The smart video laryngoscope is focused on safe and consistent intubation outcomes with less training and skills required of medical personnel. This is key to lowering the costs of airway management and improving outcomes. Airway intubation procedures currently require training periods of three to four years to achieve consistently safe and high-quality outcomes. Even so, over 1 million major complications occur in the pre-hospital, emergency room, and intensive care units yearly. Many such complications result from first-pass attempt intubation failures. Lives and dollars may be saved via improved intubation. For example, U.S. military medics perform tracheostomies on the battlefield because of the inability to safely intubate injured warriors. Reducing the skills and knowledge needed to safely intubate patients via augmentation of the video laryngoscope may positively impact such areas. Moreover, digital imaging is used to perform procedures in medicine from surgery to central line placement. The infrastructure developed in this project may be used as a template for application in other procedures for tactical and strategic outputs. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of an automated collection and archiving system of high-fidelity data for tracheal intubation procedures in aggregate. This data will improve intubation outcomes through better clinical research, quality assurance, and training feedback. The lack of data related to tracheal intubation is currently the rate-limiting step to rapidly improving  higher quality outcomes. This project is aimed at automating the recording and archiving of video-assisted intubations and then processing the data for both tactical and strategic uses. Tactically, the data may be processed in real-time by an expert system, and fed back onto the video laryngoscope display for real-time augmentation in order to provide the operator with decision support and guidance. Strategically, the recordings may be stored and processed to surveil intubation quality and quantity at any level ranging from individual performance over time to departmental, medical system, or national or worldwide performance. Currently, there is no practical way to surveil the critical procedure at any of these levels.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our technology, project-named "Marvin", applies machine vision to interpret images gained from video-laryngoscopes. Video laryngoscope are used to facilitate endotracheal intubations, i.e., the placement of breathing tubes that allow connecting patients up to a ventilator in the operating room or intensive care unit. Intubations are among the most commonly performed procedure in hospitals, and while they are very safe, they are very stressful for the provider, because they have to be completed within three to four minutes, because some patients are difficult to intubate, and because failing to intubate within the short time window will lead to brain damage or death.

When we started out in this NSF iCorps project, we were pursuing a number of potential value propositions and associated potential customers. We had demonstrated how the machine vision could identify anatomical structures and thus guide the clinician in placing the breathing tube (e.g., help prevent placing the tube into the esophagus rather than the airway). We thought this should be of value for clinicians who had to intubate but did not have the multiple-times-a-day experience that anesthesiologists have. Other value propositions included providing quality feedback to intubators and their supervisors; automatically generating procedure notes from intubations; storing intubation videos for later retrieval, esp. of difficult intubations, when a patient returns for another procedure; detecting multiple intubation attempts and automatically calling for assistance after the third attempt. We were convinced and excited about the value of our technology. But actually, we were contemplating a cacophony of too many potential value propositions, directions for our product, and associated customers and stakeholders. The complexities of the medical device associated landscape of users, beneficiaries, deciders, payors, regulators, etc.  further aggravated this situation

Over the six and a half weeks of the NSF-ICORPS workshop, the Marvin team interviewed more than one hundred stakeholders, users, payors, and experts involved in or having a stake in endotracheal intubations. Through this process we discovered that some of our initially hypothesized value propositions were either invalid or difficult/impossible to attain.  E.g., clinicians really did not appreciate having a system looking over their shoulder and assessing the quality of their work, esp. when there is a chance that information is reported to their supervisors. As another example, we learned that the number of first responder emergency medical personnel that is trained, qualified, and actual performs intubations is actually very small. A number of educators we interviewed introduced the reduction of training time as a potential value proposition. Clinical supervisors expressed great interest in the potential to improve the management of airway management, especially the reduction of the number of catastrophic outliers. But we also found that both value propositions would be difficult to quantify and as a result difficult to integrate into a revenue model. We also discovered that there are other procedures besides intubations, e.g., minimally invasive laparoscopic surgeries, that are supported by live videos that are currently neither stored for later review or perusal nor automatically interpreted.

Since the NSF-ICORPS workshop we have continued our customer discovery and our mapping out of the competitive and stakeholder landscape, taking advantage of the increasing possibilities for travel after the initial Covid restrictions had been lifted. In these activities we were able to validate the key value propositions that emerged from the workshop-phase of this project: (a) health care managers get a high-level strategic overview of enterprise-wide intubation quality metrics; (b) trainees get real-time objective feedback on their progress in acquiring intubation skills and that feedback does not require an expert trainer; and (c) infrequent intubators receive in-procedure interpretation of their video laryngoscope.

The NSF workshop and our customer discovery and business model creation activities have helped us identify the most promising path forward towards bringing our Marvin AI technology to market - and with that to the intubation point-of-care. The wide deployment of our system will help advancing, in a data-driven evidence-based manner, our understanding of the specific real-world challenges associated with airway management.  The broader impacts of this will include the avoidance of catastrophic intubation outliers, the improved training of intubators, especially of infrequent intubators. In addition, there is the potential to expand our approach to other procedures that already use videos, but do not automatically record them, interpret them, and systematically assess performance.

Following the conclusion of the NSF i-Corps project, we have now embarked on the next steps in commercializing this technology. In particular, we are raising external capital; are reengineering both the local hardware (which is retrieving, deidentifying, and forwarding the video) and the cloud data pipeline; and are approaching initial hospital system that are interested in becoming our first customers

 


Last Modified: 06/01/2022
Modified by: Kai Kuck
